abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Action Plan looks at key
            issues regarding potential adversity on socioeconomic
            aspects, resulting from the implementation of the National
            Natural Ecosystem Management Project. These issues, and
            mitigation measures are summarized as follows: 1) An
            interactive, participatory approach will be defined for the
            preparation of management plans to reduce the risk of
            revenue losses resulting from activity transfers. 2) Based
            on the institutional framework of the Ministry of the
            Environment and Water - through its coordinating units on
            wildlife conservation, natural resources management, and
            forestry preservation - the establishment of partnerships
            with local community groups, will support agricultural
            development, appropriate management of forest resources, and
            livestock activities, on a contractual basis, aimed at
            minimizing adversity on the livelihoods of local
            populations. 3) Regarding grazing, and livestock management,
            particularly concerning nomad groups, management plans will
            address key issues, namely, grazing, and livestock
            activities will be transferred to other zones, based on
            concerted agreement with affected populations, aiming at
            preserving their livelihoods, and standard of living. 4) The
            risk of increased poverty on vulnerable groups, e.g.,
            resulting from limited access to forestry resources, calls
            for immediate action, whereby the project will support
            micro-activities to access new resources, and training, to
            reduce their vulnerability. 5) Grievance mechanisms, and
            monitoring and evaluation practices, based on public
            consultations, will ensure compliance with key social indicators.
